author-notes.corresp: Cynthia A. Thomson, PhD, RD, CSO, Professor, Mel and Enid Zuckerman College of Public Health, Director, Canyon Ranch Center for Prevention & Health Promotion, University of Arizona, 1295 N Martin Ave, A260, Tucson, AZ 85724, USA; e-mail: cthomson@email.arizona.edu.

abstract.p: Background: Breast cancer is the most commonly diagnosed cancer among women in the United States. Extensive research has been completed to evaluate the relationship between dietary factors and breast cancer risk and survival after breast cancer; however, a summary report with clinical inference is needed. Materials and Methods: This review summarizes the current epidemiological and clinical trial evidence relating diet to breast cancer incidence, recurrence, survival, and mortality. The review includes emerging epidemiological studies that assess risk within breast cancer subtypes as well as a summary of previous and ongoing dietary intervention trials designed to modify breast cancer risk. Results: The available literature suggests that both low-fat and high-fiber diets may be weakly protective against breast cancer, whereas total energy intake and alcohol appear to be positively associated. Fiber may be weakly protective possibly through modulation of estrogen, whereas fruit and vegetable intake is not clearly associated with risk. Obesity is a risk factor for postmenopausal disease, and adult weight gain should be avoided to reduce risk. In survivors, diet has the greatest potential influence on overall mortality rather than breast cancer–specific events. Conclusion: Diet is modestly associated with breast cancer risk; associations appear more pronounced for postmenopausal disease, and healthy choices after diagnosis and treatment likely support longevity more so than reduced risk for recurrent disease.

body.p: Breast cancer is the most common cancer diagnosed in women, accounting for 1 of every 3 cancers diagnosed. More than 230,000 new cases of invasive disease are diagnosed annually in the United States.1 Lifetime risk has remained at approximately 1 in 8 women by 80 years of age for several decades.2 Although Hispanic and African American women have lower incidence rates compared with non-Hispanic whites (NHWs), they tend to carry a higher mortality rate; importantly, major advancements in our understanding of disease etiology and risk have supported the development of highly effective, targeted therapies to treat women diagnosed with breast cancer. In addition, there has been a significant increase in early detection of disease, with mammogram screening prevalence now estimated at 66.5% in eligible women.2 Together, these 2 factors have resulted in survival rates as high as 99% for early stage disease in NHWs and average 5-, 10-, and 15-year overall survival rates of 89%, 82%, and 77%, respectively.1 These trends have resulted in an ever-increasing population of breast cancer survivors, a group with unique dietary concerns and needs, now approaching 3 million.3

Over the past 2–3 decades, research to characterize breast cancer has demonstrated that this disease is highly variable in terms of tumor subtypes as well as the diverse etiology. Risk factors, both modifiable and not modifiable, may vary widely. This is an important concept because it not only suggests that therapies will vary, but how we quantify and qualify risk as well as what behavioral approaches are recommended to modify risk will likely need to be tailored to the individual disease classifications. Figure 1 summarizes the current diagnostic subgroups used to characterize breast cancer, key classification characteristics, and commonly prescribed therapies. Most breast cancer arises from transformation of healthy tissue into malignancy within either the lobules (lobular) or ducts (ductal) of the breast; the exception is inflammatory breast cancer, which is more diffuse and strongly correlated with an intense inflammatory response. Table 1 provides definitions of common terminology used in breast oncology.

caption.p: Breast cancer subtypes. DCIS, ductal carcinoma in situ; LCIS, lobular carcinoma in situ. Adapted from Mullan et al.4 Reprinted with kind permission from Springer Science+Business Media B.V.

tr.td: Aromatase inhibitors (AI)
Therapeutic medications designed to inhibit aromatase activity and thus suppress/arrest estrogen production.
A gene on chromosome 17 (BRCA1) or 13 (BRCA2) that normally suppresses cell growth. A person who inherits this germ-line mutation in the BRCA gene has a greater risk for developing breast cancer.
ER+

Describes cells that have a receptor protein that binds the hormone estrogen. Cancer cells that are ER+ may need estrogen to grow and may stop growing or die when treated with substances that block the binding and actions of estrogen. Also called estrogen receptor positive.
ER–

Describes cells that do not have a protein to which the hormone estrogen will bind. Cancer cells that are ER– do not need estrogen to grow and usually do not stop growing when treated with hormones that block estrogen from binding. Also called estrogen receptor negative.
Triple-negative
Describes breast cancer cells that do not have estrogen receptors, progesterone receptors, or large amounts of HER2/neu protein. Also called ER-negative PR-negative HER2/neu-negative breast cancer.
Ductal carcinoma
The most common type of breast cancer. It begins in the cells that line the milk ducts in the breast.
DCIS

Ductal carcinoma in situ; a noninvasive condition in which abnormal cells are found in the lining of a breast duct. The abnormal cells have not spread outside the duct to other tissues in the breast. In some cases, ductal carcinoma in situ may become invasive cancer and spread to other tissues, although it is not known at this time how to predict which lesions will become invasive. Also called intraductal carcinoma.
Lobular carcinoma

Cancer that begins in the lobules (the glands that make milk) of the breast. Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) is a condition in which abnormal cells are found only in the lobules. When cancer has spread from the lobules to surrounding tissues, it is invasive lobular carcinoma. LCIS does not become invasive lobular carcinoma very often, but having LCIS in one breast increases the risk of developing invasive cancer in either breast.
HER2/neu

A protein involved in normal cell growth. It is found in some types of cancer cells, including breast and ovarian. Cancer cells removed from the body may be tested for the presence of HER2/neu to help decide the best type of treatment. HER2/neu is a type of receptor tyrosine kinase. Also called c-erbB-2, human EGF receptor 2, and human epidermal growth factor receptor 2.
Local cancer
An invasive malignant cancer confined entirely to the organ where the cancer began.
Distal
Cancer of more advanced stage that has spread outside the breast/mammary tissue.
Invasive breast cancer

Cancer that has spread from where it started in the breast into surrounding, healthy tissue. Most invasive breast cancers start in the ducts (tubes that carry milk from the lobules to the nipple). Invasive breast cancer can spread to other parts of the body through the blood and lymph systems. Also called infiltrating breast cancer.
Luminal A
Breast tumor with the following characteristics: ER+ and/or PR+, HER2– with low Ki67 proliferation index.
Luminal B
Breast tumors with the following characteristics: ER+ and/or PR+, HER2+ (or HER2– with high Ki67 proliferation index).
Basal
Breast tumors with the following characteristics: triple-negative disease– ER–, PR–, HER2–, cytokeratin 5/6+, and/or HER1+.
SERM

Selective estrogen receptor modulators; therapeutic agents that bind with the estrogen receptor to markedly reduce estrogen production in select tissues at variable degrees. Target breast cells expressing estrogen.
Stages
Stage 0: carcinoma in situ
2 types: DCIS and LCIS
Stage I: In stage I, cancer has formed. Stage I is divided into stages IA and IB.
• In stage IA, the tumor is 2 cm or smaller and has not spread outside the breast.
• In stage IB, either:
No tumor is found in the breast, but small clusters of cancer cells (larger than 0.2 mm but not larger than 2 mm) are found in the lymph nodes; or
The tumor is 2 cm or smaller and small clusters of cancer cells (larger than 0.2 mm but not larger than 2 mm) are found in the lymph nodes.
Stage II: divided into stages IIA and IIB.
• In stage IIA:
No tumor is found in the breast, but cancer is found in the axillary lymph nodes (lymph nodes under the arm); or
The tumor is 2 cm or smaller and has spread to the axillary lymph nodes; or
The tumor is larger than 2 cm but not larger than 5 cm and has not spread to the axillary lymph nodes.
• In stage IIB, the tumor is either:
Larger than 2 cm but not larger than 5 cm and has spread to the axillary lymph nodes; or
Larger than 5 cm but has not spread to the axillary lymph nodes.
• No tumor is found in the breast. Cancer is found in axillary lymph nodes that are attached to each other or to other structures, or cancer is found in lymph nodes near the breastbone; or
• The tumor is 2 cm or smaller. Cancer has spread to axillary lymph nodes that are attached to each other or to other structures, or cancer has spread to lymph nodes near the breastbone; or

• The tumor is larger than 2 cm but not larger than 5 cm. Cancer has spread to axillary lymph nodes that are attached to each other or to other structures, or cancer has spread to lymph nodes near the breastbone; or
• The tumor is larger than 5 cm. Cancer has spread to axillary lymph nodes that may be attached to each other or to other structures, or cancer may have spread to lymph nodes near the breastbone.
In stage IIIB, the tumor may be any size and cancer:
• Has spread to the chest wall and/or the skin of the breast; and
• May have spread to axillary lymph nodes that may be attached to each other or to other structures, or cancer may have spread to lymph nodes near the breastbone.
Cancer that has spread to the skin of the breast is inflammatory breast cancer. See the section on Inflammatory Breast Cancer for more information.
In stage IIIC, no tumor is found in the breast or the tumor may be any size and may have spread to the chest wall and/or the skin of the breast. Also, cancer:
• Has spread to lymph nodes above or below the collarbone; and
• May have spread to axillary lymph nodes or to lymph nodes near the breastbone.
Cancer that has spread to the skin of the breast is inflammatory breast cancer. See the section on Inflammatory Breast Cancer for more information.
Stage IIIC breast cancer is divided into operable and inoperable stage IIIC.
In operable stage IIIC, the cancer:
• Is found in 10 or more axillary lymph nodes; or
• Is found in lymph nodes below the collarbone; or
• Is found in axillary lymph nodes and in lymph nodes near the breastbone.
In inoperable stage IIIC breast cancer, the cancer has spread to the lymph nodes above the collarbone.
In stage IV, the cancer has spread to other organs of the body, most often the bones, lungs, liver, or brain.

fn.label: a
fn.p: Adapted from the National Institutes of Health/National Cancer Institute website (www.cancer.gov/dictionary), accessed June 5, 2012.

sec.title: Risk Factors
sec.p: Several established risk factors for breast cancer have been identified, including hormone therapy, obesity, family history, and age. Among the most modifiable risk factors is diet (see Table 2). The purpose of this review is to provide an overview of breast oncology and the current evidence linking dietary factors to risk and prevention of breast cancer. Both primary prevention and tertiary prevention will be addressed. Some emphasis will be placed on modifiable diet after breast cancer treatment and survival as this is the population most likely to seek nutrition intervention and counseling.

caption.p: Modifiable and Nonmodifiable Risk for Breast Cancer

tr.td: Age
Biopsy-confirmed atypical hyperplasia
High breast density
BRCA1,2 mutation
Personal history of breast cancer
High bone density
High-dose radiation to chest
Family history (2 or more)
Ashkenazi Jewish heritage
Early menarche (<12 years)
Height
Family history (1 relative)
High endogenous estrogen or testosterone
Hormone therapy (long term with estrogen and progesterone)
Alcohol consumption
Late age at first full-term pregnancy
Never breastfed
Obesity (postmenopause)
High dietary fat intake
Adult weight gain (20 kg)

fn.p: Adapted from Breast Cancer Facts and Figures, American Cancer Society, 2011–2012.1

sec.title: Diet and Breast Cancer: Primary Prevention
sec.p: Diet is thought to play a significant role in modifying overall cancer risk. Recently, the American Cancer Society (ACS) released the 2012 Guidelines on Nutrition and Physical Activity for Cancer Prevention5 (Table 3). In general, these guidelines are supported by evidence suggesting that diet plays a role in breast cancer prevention as well.

caption.p: American Cancer Society (ACS) Guidelines for Nutrition and Physical Activity for Cancer Prevention5

tr.td: • Achieve and maintain a healthy weight throughout life.
• Be as lean as possible throughout life without being underweight.
• Avoid excess weight gain at all ages. For those who are currently overweight or obese, losing even a small amount of weight has health benefits and is a good place to start.
• Engage in regular physical activity and limit consumption of high-calorie foods and beverages as key strategies for maintaining a healthy weight.

• Adopt a physically active lifestyle. Adults should engage in at least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity or 75 minutes of vigorous-intensity activity each week, or an equivalent combination, preferably spread throughout the week. Children and adolescents should engage in at least 1 hour of moderate- or vigorous-intensity activity each day, with vigorous-intensity activity occurring at least 3 days each week.

• Limit sedentary behavior such as sitting, lying down, watching television, or other forms of screen-based entertainment. Doing some physical activity above usual activities, no matter what one’s level of activity, can have many health benefits.
• Consume a healthy diet, with an emphasis on plant foods.
• Choose foods and beverages in amounts that help achieve and maintain a healthy weight.
• Limit consumption of processed meat and red meat.
• Eat at least 2.5 cups of vegetables and fruits each day.
• Choose whole grains instead of refined grain products.
• If you drink alcoholic beverages, limit consumption. Drink no more than 1 drink per day for women or 2 per day for men.

sec.p: In 2007, the World Cancer Research Fund in collaboration with the American Institute for Cancer Research (WCRF/AICR) published an expansive summary document describing the consensus findings from epidemiological research of the association between key dietary factors and breast cancer risk.6 This report indicated that although alcohol was the dietary exposure most consistently associated with risk for breast cancer, weight gain in adulthood and current obesity/body fat were also associated with increased risk for breast cancer, although predominantly in postmenopausal women.

sec.title: Alcohol
sec.p: The evidence suggesting alcohol may increase breast cancer risk continues to mount. A recent analysis from the Nurses’ Health Study affirmed earlier research suggesting that even low to moderate alcohol intake may increase breast cancer risk, particularly for postmenopausal women.7 In this recent analysis, risk was increased regardless of the source of alcohol, be it wine (red or white), beer, or spirits. This is one of the few reports also to evaluate patterns of alcohol consumption. The data suggested that binge drinking as well as drinking habits earlier in adulthood may further exacerbate risk, and these factors will need to be evaluated on a more consistent basis in future studies assessing these relationships. In the Women’s Health Initiative (WHI) observational study cohort that included 87,724 postmenopausal women and 2944 incident cases of breast cancer over 5 years of follow-up, alcohol intake at the level of 1 drink daily was associated with an 82% greater risk for hormone receptor–positive lobular breast cancer.8 A follow-up analysis that evaluated these relationships by tumor type found estrogen receptor–positive (ER+) disease to be associated with alcohol intake, including separate analysis by intake of wine or liquor. In this same analysis, women who reported alcohol intake showed a lower risk for triple-negative disease.9 No increased risk for invasive ductal breast cancer was shown. Investigation into the associated risk for breast cancer among BRCA mutation carriers who drink alcohol suggested there was no increase in risk and perhaps a protective relationship for wine intake in BRCA1 mutation carriers.10

The exact mechanism by which alcohol may increase breast cancer risk has not been elucidated. A reduction in folate and available methyl donors for DNA stability is one plausible mechanism. Earlier work from Harvard that has been corroborated by several other epidemiological studies suggested that the breast cancer risk associated with alcohol might be attenuated in women who reported a diet with adequate folate intake.11 A recent study of breast tumor characteristics suggested that among those reporting higher adulthood alcohol intake, there is a significant increase in DNA methylation of target promoter genes, and this may account for the increase in risk shown.12 Alternately, changes in circulating estrogen may account for the increase in risk.13 This recent analysis suggests that alcohol increases breast cancer risk independent of folate status,7 associations that may have been altered in response to the overall reduction in population-level folate deficiency in the United States following food fortification.14

sec.title: Dietary Fat
sec.p: The WCRF/AICR report indicated that evidence, although limited, was suggestive of an increase in breast cancer risk among postmenopausal women consuming higher fat diets as compared with those consuming lower fat diets.6 The role of dietary fat in breast cancer primary prevention has been studied in one of the largest randomized controlled dietary trials ever conducted in the United States, the WHI Dietary Modification Trial. The study randomized 48,835 postmenopausal women to either a low-fat diet (20% total energy; 40% sample) or usual dietary fat intake (60% of sample). The details of the study design have been described previously.15 Briefly, women in the intervention groups attended group classes led by a registered dietitian monthly, and then quarterly, for 4 years. Motivational interviewing, cognitive behavioral therapy, and group social support were all integrated to promote behavior change. After 8.1 years of follow-up, there was no significant difference in the number of newly diagnosed breast cancer cases in the women enrolled in the treatment vs control conditions.16 However, a subgroup analysis suggested that among women who entered the trial with higher habitual dietary fat intake (>36.8% total energy intake), breast cancer rates were reduced by 22%.16 Total energy intake, when adjusted for self-report error using a doubly labeled water-derived calibration equation, was also inversely associated with breast cancer risk.17 In an assessment of predictors of dietary fat reduction, the WHI investigators found that younger age, more education, more optimism, and greater attendance at classes and self-monitoring all supported favorable dietary change.18

Another randomized controlled trial studying the primary prevention of breast cancer, which enrolled 4690 Canadian women with high mammographic breast density into a low-fat group (20% energy) or a usual-diet group, also found no significant effect of the intervention.19 In this trial, both pre- and postmenopausal women were enrolled (mean age 47.1 years) and followed for an average of 10 years. In subgroup analysis, greater baseline body weight as well as lower carbohydrate intake was associated with greater risk for ER+ disease; the number of ER– cases was too small for statistical evaluation.

In addition to these intervention trials, epidemiological evidence suggests that dietary fat is modestly associated with breast cancer risk,6 and type of dietary fat consumed may also influence risk. A meta-analysis of 57 studies conducted both in the United States and internationally indicated that saturated fat intake is associated with an increased risk for postmenopausal disease, polyunsaturated fats were associated with increased risk regardless of menopausal status, and monounsaturated fats had no significant association with risk.20 In 1 study assessing risk related to tumor subtypes, vegetable oil–based margarine was associated with a 31% greater risk of ER–/progesterone receptor–negative (PR–) tumors.21

In addition, a high-fat eating pattern (>40% of energy as fat), characterized by higher intake of processed meats, margarine, butter, and other animal fats, was associated with a 2-fold greater risk for breast cancer in a population sample of 15,351 women with 137 incident cases of invasive breast cancer. Furthermore, the risk was not modified by obesity, menopausal status, or even hormone therapy use.22 Of interest, a well-designed crossover feeding trial evaluating the effect of dietary fat on sex hormones, a plausible pathway for fat modulation of breast cancer risk, found a 51% increase in plasma estradiol with high-fat feeding but no association between n-3 fatty acids and hormone concentrations.23

Low fat diets may have a role in reducing age-associated weight gain in postmenopausal women and thus indirectly lower breast cancer risk.24 Women randomized in the WHI Diet Modification low-fat diet arm, on average, also demonstrated a modest reduction in body weight during the early years of the intervention. Although this initial weight loss was followed by a steady increase in weight over the 7.2 years of follow-up, the trajectory of weight loss never reached the higher levels demonstrated in the usual-care group.

sec.title: Red and Processed Meat
sec.p: Studies also have evaluated the role of red meat and/or processed meat and breast cancer risk but to date provide inconsistent results. A 2010 meta-analysis supported the WCRF/AICR findings that suggested there was no conclusive evidence that red meat or processed meat acts as an independent risk factor for breast cancer.25 Efforts to evaluate these associations by tumor subtype are warranted.

sec.title: Dietary Fiber
sec.p: The 2007 WCRF/AICR report6 did not identify any specific foods or additional food components associated with risk of breast cancer. However, several dietary components do warrant discussion as the evidence, albeit limited in terms of number and quality, provides guidance in terms of what we tell our patients. For example, dietary fiber, which has been shown to modify estrogen concentrations,26 appeared to reduce ER+ disease.27,28

sec.title: Vegetable, Fruit, and Legume Intake
sec.p: The relationship between greater fruit and vegetable intake and reduced risk for breast cancer has not been consistently demonstrated, particularly for U.S. cohorts.6 This may be related to the overall lower intake of fruits and vegetables in the United States or the reduced amounts of constitutive bioactive compounds in fruit and vegetables selections (State of the Plate: http://www.pbhfoundation.org/pdfs/about/res/pbh_res/stateplate.pdf). Soybeans, a legume of the plant family, have been specifically identified for their potential protective association with breast cancer. Soybeans contain several bioactive compounds, including phytic acid, α-linolenic acid, and isoflavones thought to promote health through antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and estrogen-modulating effects. A meta-analysis of 18 epidemiological studies of dietary soy intake suggested that high vs low soy intake was associated with a modest 14% reduced risk for breast cancer.29 Protection was more evident in premenopausal women. The studies evaluated were highly heterogeneous, and it is not possible to draw clear conclusions based on this meta-analysis or the evidence at large. Certainly, soy is a reasonable and healthy source of protein and other bioactives in the diet, but high consumption is likely only to demonstrate a protective effect in the context of other cancer-protective dietary behaviors.

sec.title: Dietary Patterns
sec.p: Although several nutrients or dietary components have been associated with breast cancer risk modification, there is a paucity of evidence evaluating the role of whole dietary patterns. A review of the evidence in 2009 suggested that no clear conclusions could be drawn30; however, some limited evidence supports the role of the Mediterranean diet.31 Mechanistically, in addition to reducing oxidative stress, increasing satiety, and promoting an anti-inflammatory state, the Mediterranean diet may be protective against breast cancer through the suppression of Her2 oncogene expression by oleic acid (olive oil)32 or a suppression of circulating estrogenic hormones in postmenopausal women.33

Evidence from 3 association studies supports the hypothesis that healthier diets, combined with physically active lifestyles, can reduce breast cancer risk even in those at greatest risk for this disease. Specifically, female carriers of the BRCA1,2 germ-line mutations for breast cancer show a reduction in overall risk as well as a delay in age of disease diagnosis if they report having maintained a healthy body weight, generally through active lifestyle and healthy eating habits during adolescence and early adult life.34 Higher dietary quality scores are associated with reduced odds for developing breast cancer in BRCA1 and BRCA2 carriers.35

sec.title: Body Weight
sec.p: Although not a major focus of this review, body weight6 has been consistently associated with greater risk for postmenopausal but not premenopausal disease. This is particularly true for luminal-type tumors and possibly also for the triple-negative tumor subtype in women not using hormone therapy.36 These associations have not been seen in women taking hormone therapy. As most breast cancer is ER+, there appears to be a significant role for circulating estrogen in imparting risk. In the absence of the higher exogenous exposure associated with prescription hormone use greater body fat equates to greater circulating estrogens.37 Prior to menopause, the adipose-associated estrogen is low relative to the total available estrogen. Thus, obesity after menopause represents a significant increase in normal circulating hormones above what is expected at this age for those who maintain a healthy body weight. The “hyperestrogenic” host environment may explain the differential association of obesity with breast cancer prior to vs after menopause.

Some interesting research in rats wherein net energy availability was modified through energy restriction, physical activity, or both suggested that estrogen may not be the primary causal pathway for obesity-associated disease, but alternatively, insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) and related insulin levels could be driving risk.38 Relevant to this observation, a meta-analysis showed that waist circumference, an indicator of central adiposity and insulin resistance, increased risk for premenopausal breast cancer by 79% and postmenopausal breast cancer by 50%. These data indicate that regardless of age, efforts to control visceral adiposity are imperative to control breast cancer risk.39 Finally, a recent meta-analysis of 11 studies suggested that adult weight gain is predictive of a 2-fold increase in the risk for ER+ as well as ER+/PR+ breast tumors, with risk greatest among postmenopausal (risk estimate of 2.3) as compared with premenopausal disease (risk estimate of 1.54).40

In summary, the evidence for an association between dietary practices and breast cancer is substantial. Some factors appear to be protective in reducing risk, whereas others may promote breast cancer. Certainly, limiting alcohol intake is one important approach to reducing risk. Current evidence is also suggestive that greater fiber intake26 and lower fat intake in postmenopausal women with high habitual fat intake through modulation of estradiol levels may reduce breast cancer risk,16 as can lower overall energy intake.17 Although most evidence has not consistently supported the role of greater vegetable intake in reducing breast cancer risk, most healthcare providers continue to promote varied and bioactive-rich vegetable intake owing to the theory that exposures above current intake and that are habitual could feasibly reduce risk.

sec.title: Dietary Concerns During Therapy
sec.p: Once diagnosed with breast cancer, patients have a plethora of treatment modalities to “cure” this disease. Treatment will vary by disease stage, grade, proliferation, and molecular markers as well as evidence of tumor spread to lymph nodes or other organs. The dietetic approaches will vary with individual therapy as well as the individual response to therapies. Approaches to diet therapy to be employed during breast and other cancer treatments have been described previously41 and thus are only briefly described below.

sec.title: Surgery
sec.p: Almost every breast cancer diagnosis will be treated surgically, either with lumpectomy or mastectomy. As much as possible, those diagnosed with breast cancer should be encouraged to increase intake of lean protein sources, as well as foods rich in vitamin A, zinc, and vitamin C prior to surgery to promote optimal healing and immune function prior to and after surgery. Although no randomized trials have been conducted to specifically test the role of presurgical diet therapy for optimal breast cancer surgical outcomes, knowledge of the importance of diet in healing supports this approach. Supplementation of the diet with targeted nutrients is likely to afford additional benefit in terms of postsurgical healing and reduced risk for infection in women who demonstrate inadequacies in their diet. Dietary practices should be evaluated and recommendations to correct deficiency should be made prior to surgery if possible.

sec.title: Chemotherapy
sec.p: Chemotherapy, when indicated, may be administered prior to (neoadjuvant) or after surgery. The most common chemotherapeutic regimes include cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin (Adriamycin), paclitaxel (Taxol), and docetaxol (Taxotere), although methotrexate, fluorouracil, and bevacizumab are also used. Therapy usually runs 3–6 months and for many women is relatively well tolerated. Common side effects of chemotherapy for breast cancer include nausea, fatigue, and changes in appetite. Most breast cancer patients will not demonstrate problems with weight loss during chemotherapy; many will be weight stable, although undesirable weight gain has been demonstrated.42 The mechanisms of weight change are likely multifactorial, including reduced metabolic rate, reduced lean mass, increased fat mass, reduced physical activity, loss of bone mass, and hormonal changes.43 One report suggested that overeating was not a major contributing factor.44 Yet, it is prudent to suggest that dietary intervention during treatment should include regular evaluation of net energy balance and should promote weight stabilization through changes in energy intake, physical activity, or both. Of note, chemotherapy in some studies has been associated with a reduction in lean mass and an increase in fat mass.44 Thus, efforts should be made to integrate both aerobic as well as strength-training activities throughout therapy to promote cardiovascular health along with retention of lean mass.45 Although protein supplementation, including concentrated leucine intake, has been shown to increase skeletal muscle mass in aging individuals46 and mice with cancer cachexia,47 no studies have been conducted to evaluate efficacy in the postchemotherapy period. When promoting higher quality protein intake to arrest lean body mass loss, evidence suggests intake should be distributed throughout the day, with meals.48 Adequate hydration with low-osmolarity fluids is also recommended to reduce the risk for constipation.

sec.title: Radiation
sec.p: Radiation therapy is commonly used to treat breast cancer, even early stage disease. Dietary concerns related to radiation therapy are limited. Fatigue is a common side effect and can significantly reduce physical activity, leading to weight gain. The approach here is to prevent treatment-associated weight gain through regularly monitoring body weight, promoting daily physical activity, and reducing energy intake to compensate for any reduced expenditure. Most patients will do best with small, short bouts of activity throughout the day that can be integrated into daily activities.

sec.title: Hormonal Therapies
sec.p: Select estrogen receptor modulators such as tamoxifen were introduced on a broad scale to treat breast cancer in the 1980s; in more recent times, targeted estrogen-targeted medications that inhibit aromatase, the primary enzyme responsible for estrogen production, have been used to treat ER tumors. The aromatase inhibitors, or AIs, demonstrate efficacy similar to selective ER modulators (SERMs) with less endometrial toxicity. Both SERMs and AIs are associated with significant side effects related to the suppression of estrogen, including insomnia, hot flushes, fatigue, and in some cases weight gain; AIs also increase cardiovascular disease risk and fracture risk.49 Recent association studies suggest that cruciferous vegetables and also dietary soy may enhance the effects of tamoxifen on breast cancer.50,51 Similar interactions between AIs and dietary constituents have not been studied.

sec.title: Breast Cancer Survival
sec.p: Survival rates for early stage breast cancer have increased remarkably since the introduction of estrogen-modulating therapies. A woman diagnosed with early stage disease has a 98% chance of being cancer free 5 years later, and survival rates remain, on average, more than 77% even 10–15 years after treatment.1 Several dietary factors have been evaluated in terms of the influence on breast cancer survival, and the evidence has recently been summarized in the ACS expert report.52 Among the most comprehensively explored factors is body weight.

sec.title: Body Weight
sec.p: The role of body weight before and following breast cancer treatment in relation to breast cancer recurrence and survival is an area of active research and some controversy. Many53-57 but not all58,59 studies evaluating these associations have shown an increased risk for breast cancer events in women who are overweight/obese at the time of diagnosis. The degree of obesity is an important indicator of risk, as ascertained in one of the largest studies to date, the After Breast Cancer Pooling Project, a prospective analysis of almost 15,000 invasive breast cancer cases from 12 cohort and intervention studies of breast cancer. A recent analysis evaluating body size and breast cancer prognosis showed no association between body mass index (BMI) and recurrent disease, an increase in breast cancer mortality only in the morbidly obese (BMI ≥40 kg/m2), and a significant increase in non–breast cancer and total mortality in the severe and morbidly obese.59 This study did not specifically address contralateral disease, but some studies have shown an increased risk for contralateral disease vs recurrent disease in obese women diagnosed with ER+ tumors.60,61

Central adiposity also has been shown to be associated with future risk for second primary or contralateral disease,62,63 suggesting that clinicians should consider regular measurement of waist circumference in breast cancer survivors to more fully estimate risk and guide care. In 1 study of 1254 younger patients with breast cancer, abdominal adiposity also was associated with a 52% increase in overall mortality based on the National Death Index collected over a 10-year period.64

Importantly, low BMI (<18.5 kg/m2) has been associated with poorer breast cancer prognosis.59,65,66 This may be partially explained by the fact that underweight women appear to be particularly vulnerable to treatment-associated weight gain.57 In an analysis from the Nurses’ Health Study in nonsmokers, those who gained as little as 0.5–2.0 kg during therapy demonstrated a 35% increase in risk of breast cancer death,56 but more recent studies since the regular prescription of hormone-modulating therapies have not demonstrated a relationship between weight gain during therapy and recurrent disease risk.57

sec.title: Diabetes and Obesity-Related Comorbidities
sec.p: A few obesity-associated risk factors can increase the risk for recurrent disease and/or increase overall mortality. In an analysis by Patterson et al,67 breast cancer survivors who were diagnosed with diabetes demonstrated a 2-fold greater risk for recurrent or new breast cancer events as well as a 2.5-fold higher overall mortality. Similar adverse outcomes were reported from a UK study in which prediagnosis diabetes inferred a 32% higher risk of cancer mortality.68 Cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and hypertension in combination also increased overall mortality in the Women’s Healthy Eating and Living (WHEL) study women67 and could suggest earlier onset of chronic disease after therapy. Importantly, the average survivor in this analysis also demonstrated a high BMI both at the time of diagnosis and after therapy for breast cancer. In a recruitment cohort for a small weight loss intervention, Thomson et al.30 found overweight breast cancer survivors to demonstrate prediabetes/metabolic syndrome rates of just over 50%.68 These data support the need for weight control and glucose/insulin control postdiagnosis in this vulnerable population. In addition, evidence is mounting to suggest that metformin, a drug commonly prescribed for glucose control, improves breast cancer prognosis in select subtypes, including HER2+ disease.28,69,70

sec.title: Diet Interventions to Reduce Recurrence and Breast Cancer–Associated Mortality
sec.p: Although dietary intervention trials to reduce the risk for breast cancer recurrence are limited and generally show only limited efficacy,71 some discussion of subgroup analyses is warranted as these findings do inform as potential dietary strategies that are most likely to improve health and modify risk for new or recurrent breast cancer. The first study to evaluate dietary intervention for breast cancer survival on a large scale was the Women’s Intervention Nutrition Study (WINS). This study recruited more than 2500 postmenopausal women treated with early stage breast cancer (see Table 4).72 After 5 years of follow-up, an interim efficacy analysis with differential group follow-up showed a 24% survival benefit for women randomized to the low-fat group (15% total energy) vs the usual-diet group.73 These findings were corroborated by an earlier epidemiological analysis by Heber,74 who showed that a higher intake of butter, margarine, and lard was associated with a 30% higher risk for recurrent disease, and Saxe et al,75 who demonstrated an increase in both recurrent disease and breast cancer mortality in women with reported higher fat intake. Another association study by Zhang et al11 showed a hazard ratio for breast cancer mortality of 2.5 (1.2-5.3) in 698 women treated for breast cancer in the 1990s who reported higher fat intake, consistent with findings from another cohort of 4441 survivors wherein overall but not breast cancer–associated mortality was increased by 41% and 78% in relation to high intake of saturated fat and trans fats, respectively.76 However, studies are not consistent in identifying significant associations, and several have not supported an association between fat intake and recurrent disease or breast cancer mortality.77,78

caption.p: Intervention and Select Prospective Cohort Studies in the United States Evaluating the Relationship Between Diet and Breast Cancer Outcomes

tr.td: Women’s Intervention Nutrition Study (WINS)
Randomized controlled trial of a low-fat (15% total energy) vs usual diet. Dietitian on site and telephone counseling
2437 postmenopausal women previously treated for invasive breast cancer; patients enrolled within 1 year posttreatment
Interim analysis suggested a 24% reduced risk for relapse events (9.8% of low-fat group; 124% of control group), P = .034, adjusted Cox model.71

After 7 years of follow-up, overall mortality was shown to be equal across the study groups; mortality was lower in the low-fat group (7.6% vs 18.1%) in women diagnosed and treated for ER+/PR+ disease.
Women’s Healthy Eating and Living (WHEL) study
Randomized comparison group trial of a plant-based, low-fat, high-fiber diet. Telephone-based counseling by trained counselors under supervision of dietitian
3088 pre- and postmenopausal women previously treated for invasive breast cancer; enrolled, on average, 2.3 years following primary treatment
No significant difference in new or recurrent breast cancer events between diet groups was shown.78

Subsample analysis showed that higher plasma carotenoid concentrations before80 and during81 the study were associated with reduced recurrent disease that may be explained by a reduction in oxidative stress.102

Subgroup analysis also suggested the plant-based diet reduced breast cancer events in women who reported no hot flash symptoms103 as well as tamoxifen users who reported higher vegetable/cruciferous vegetable intake.97
Vitamin D status was not associated with overall mortality, breast cancer recurrence, or new breast cancer events.88
Soy intake was not associated with breast cancer recurrent or new events.86
Health, Eating, Activity and Lifestyle (HEAL) study
Prospective cohort
688 early stage breast cancer patients, following primary treatments
Fiber was not associated with a significant difference in overall mortality or new breast cancer events.84
Healthy Eating Index 2005 was associated with reduced overall mortality.91
Living After Cancer Epidemiology (LACE) study
Prospective cohort
Soy intake was associated with a 52% lower risk for postmenopausal recurrent breast cancer in women taking tamoxifen.51
Prudent diet was associated with lower overall mortality after breast cancer.92
Alcohol intake >6 g or 0.5 serving/d was associated with a 35% increase in recurrence compared with no drinking, predominantly in postmenopausal women.94
Nurses’ Health Study
Mediterranean diet was associated with lower non–breast cancer mortality after breast cancer.32
Prudent diet was associated with lower overall mortality after breast cancer.77
RENEW: Reach out to ENhance/Leading the Way in Exercise and Diet (Project LEAD) Wellness in older cancer survivors
Randomized controlled behavior modification trial; home based
641 older, long-term survivors of breast, prostate, and colorectal cancer
Pending104,105
FRESH START
Sequentially, tailored mailed diet and exercise intervention
543 newly diagnosed breast and prostate cancer survivors
Significant increases in fruit and vegetable intake, as well as exercise minutes, and reductions in total and saturated fat were demonstrated at 1-year follow-up.106
Two-year outcomes in tailored group showed continued reduction in total and saturated fat, improved overall diet quality, and increased fruit and vegetables.101
CHOICE study
Randomized 2-arm comparison trial of low-fat vs low-carbohydrate diets for weight loss
370 overweight or obese postmenopausal breast cancer patients
Pending107

fn.p: ER+, estrogen receptor positive; ER–, estrogen receptor negative.

sec.p: A second randomized controlled study of 3008 pre- and postmenopausal breast cancer survivors, also with early stage disease, resulted in null findings.79 In the WHEL study, survivors were randomized to 1 of 2 study arms: a low-fat, high-fiber, plant-based diet that was prescribed or the ACS guidelines for cancer preventive eating.80 After 7.3 years of follow-up, new and recurrent breast cancer events were similar across the 2 arms, suggesting that the plant-based diet had no benefit above the ACS guidelines. What has been gleaned from analysis of this cohort is that women who enter and maintain higher plasma carotenoids (as a result of greater vegetable and fruit intake) demonstrated reduced overall mortality,81 and a survival benefit was demonstrated in women with high plasma concentrations of carotenoids throughout the 6 years of measurement.82 Of interest, women who entered the study with higher fruit and vegetable intake combined with greater physical activity demonstrated lower overall mortality, regardless of their BMI at the time of study entry, suggesting these dietary behaviors may trump adverse effects of high body weight on overall mortality.83

sec.title: Other Diet Components: Fiber, ω-3 Fatty Acids, Soy, and Select Vitamins
sec.p: The WHEL study also identified a protective role for dietary fiber in that high fiber intake was associated with a reduction in circulating estrogen,26 and estrogen in turn was inversely associated with new breast cancer events84 in WHEL study participants. These data are consistent with findings from the Healthy Eating, Activity and Lifestyle Study (HEAL) cohort demonstrating a nonsignificant 32% reduction in breast cancer–specific mortality in women consuming higher amounts of fiber.85

An additional analysis from WHEL also suggested that high ω-3 fatty acids, including docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) and eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) intake from foods, were associated with a reduction in breast cancer events as well as a modest reduction in all-cause mortality.86 The association between soy intake and breast cancer recurrence risk, particularly for women diagnosed with ER+ disease, has been an area of controversy for several years. Recent large cohort analysis has not shown any adverse effects of dietary soy intake postdiagnosis. In fact, data from the Life After Cancer Epidemiology study (LACE) showed a 52% reduced risk for recurrent disease among postmenopausal women taking tamoxifen.53 Results from a similar analysis with the WHEL cohort found no protective or harmful association between soy intake and breast cancer outcomes,87 and in Chinese women (n = 524), high soy intake was shown to reduce breast cancer recurrence by 33% as compared with low intake but only in women with postmenopausal, not premenopausal, disease.88

Vitamin D status, as assessed by circulating concentrations of 25(OH)D, was not associated with reduced breast or overall mortality in the WHEL study population.89 However, higher intakes of calcium90 and vitamin C91 at the time of diagnosis have been associated with reduced overall mortality in women diagnosed with breast cancer and β-carotene intake with a 52% reduction in breast cancer mortality.91

sec.title: Diet Quality Indexes
sec.p: Several cohort analyses have been conducted to determine if eating patterns are protective against new or recurrent breast cancer events. Overall, there is no evidence to date to suggest diet patterns are protective for these outcomes, but several studies have identified protection in relation to overall mortality after breast cancer. The HEAL multiethnic cohort has also explored the relationship between diet and breast cancer prognosis. Data from 670 women with local or regional breast cancer followed for 6 years suggested that postdiagnosis diet quality, as assessed using the Healthy Eating Index–2005 scores, reduced overall mortality by 60% and breast cancer mortality by 88%.92 These results are supported by an observational study in 1901 breast cancer survivors in the LACE cohort that showed a 43% reduction in mortality in women who reported a dietary pattern that included greater vegetable and fruit intake combined with higher whole grain and poultry intake.93 Evidence from the Nurses’ Health Study did not show any of the 4 diet patterns tested to be associated with improved survival after breast cancer, but higher alternate Mediterranean diet score was associated with lower non–breast cancer death in survivors who reported low physical activity.94 Similar results were found in the Nurses’ Health Study in terms of a protective association for the prudent diet vs the Western diet and overall mortality of breast cancer survivors.78

sec.title: Alcohol and Breast Cancer Recurrence
sec.p: A few studies have examined the role of alcohol in breast cancer recurrence. Analysis from the 1897 survivors enrolled in the LACE cohort, of whom 49% were reported abstainers, suggested that intake of 6 g alcohol per day, or just over 3 drinks or more per week, increased recurrence risk by 35%,95 and risk was greatest for overweight/obese women. However, light alcohol intake, regardless of body weight, was not associated with recurrent disease in the WHEL study sample and in fact was associated with a 31% reduction in overall mortality in nonobese women.96 In the WHEL sample, alcohol intake was higher in women with more favorable tumor prognostic indicators (stage, estrogen status, grade, etc), and for over a third of women, intake was adjusted downward from their usual intake levels after they received a breast cancer diagnosis and prior to enrollment in the WHEL study. These factors may account for the differential findings in these 2 analyses. Evidence from European cohorts suggests that prediagnosis alcohol intake of 1 beverage per day is associated with reduced 10-year survival after breast cancer.97

sec.title: Weight Control
sec.p: Only a few weight loss studies have been conducted in breast cancer survivors, and neither evaluated follow-up breast cancer events or mortality. A small study by Thomson et al98 suggested that a weight loss intervention that included counseling by a registered dietitian resulted in significant weight loss over 3 and 6 months. Importantly, the weight loss was accompanied by a significant reduction in unfavorable metabolic markers, including HbA1c, insulin, and total and low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol. These findings have recently been replicated in a 6-month weight loss intervention in 142 overweight breast cancer survivors wherein lipid profiles and glucose improved with weight loss therapy.99 A larger multicenter weight loss intervention trial that includes energy restriction in combination with physical activity is currently under way and should provide a more definitive answer regarding the potential for lifestyle interventions, with weight control, to improve breast cancer outcomes (Dr Cheryl Rock, personal communication, University of California at San Diego, March 2012).

sec.title: Dietary Change in Response to Breast Cancer Diagnosis
sec.p: Dietary habits of breast cancer survivors have been described in the literature. In a study of WHEL study participants, self-reported data suggested that survivors made several changes to their eating habits after diagnosis. Specifically, the 3088 predominantly NHW survivors reported an increase in fruit and vegetable intake and a reduction in dietary fat intake.100 A more recent report of dietary habits in 260 women immediately postdiagnosis with breast cancer and again 2 years later did not show appreciable changes in diet over the 2-year, postdiagnosis period.101 What is currently unknown is whether lifestyle counseling during the early posttreatment period may be effective in improving diet quality. Recent work from Christy et al102 addressed this issue and suggested that mailed, tailored behavioral counseling information resulted in a significant decrease in total and saturated fat intake, an increase in fruit and vegetable intake, and better overall diet quality over a 2-year period.

sec.title: Remaining Challenges/Research Gaps
sec.p: Based on currently available epidemiological evidence as well as a wealth of basic molecular and cellular studies of breast cancer, it is clear dietary exposures do influence breast cancer risk. In fact, diet may represent one of the most modifiable risk factors for disease. Current evidence suggests that healthy dietary habits to reduce breast cancer risk should begin early in life. Evidence also suggests that although risk reduction may be modest for any one factor studied in an adult population, theoretically longer term (lifelong) protective dietary choices will reduce overall risk over time. Among the most convincing of evidence is a reduction in alcohol and total fat intake, a high-fiber diet after menopause, weight control through adult life and particularly after menopause, and, to a modest degree, an increase in vegetable intake. Clinicians should also be aware of the increase in overall mortality associated with higher rates of obesity, cardiovascular disease, and diabetes after breast cancer treatment. Supporting patients who have been previously diagnosed and treated for breast cancer who pursue healthier dietary patterns can modify and improve overall health.
